CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) is a Singaporean Code of Practice for construction documentation, specifically focusing on the organization and layering of information within digital models and drawings.  Developed by the Technical Committee on Construction Industry IT Standards, it defines a standardized layer naming convention to facilitate interoperability and data exchange between different stakeholders in the AEC industry.  The document includes clauses outlining scope, purpose, definitions, and the conceptual framework for the layering system, along with illustrative examples.  Annexes provide alphabetical lists of main and recommended sub-elements, while tables and figures detail the specific codes and formatting rules for layer names. This standardization aims to improve efficiency and reduce errors in construction projects.

elements.summary: This document details CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015), a Singaporean Code of Practice for CAD Layer Names in construction documentation.  Developed by a technical committee and referencing various publications, it aims to streamline CAD layer usage across building and infrastructure projects for electronic submissions.  Key updates include a revised list of main and sub-elements offering greater flexibility for users (architects, engineers, contractors) and alignment with government platforms like URA's EDA and BCA's eSS.  The document outlines the scope, purpose, definitions, and concepts of the code, providing examples and listing main/sub-elements.  Tables and figures detail layer name formats, codes for originators, presentation, and status fields, and element classification.  The code is supported by CAD software vendors and training is available through BCA.

pages.summary: CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015) is a Singaporean Code of Practice defining standardized CAD layer naming conventions for construction documentation.  Developed to improve interoperability and data exchange in the AEC industry, it outlines the scope, purpose, definitions, and conceptual framework for organizing information in digital models and drawings.  Key features include tables and figures detailing layer name formats, originator codes, element classification, and presentation/status codes, along with annexes listing main and sub-elements.  The code has been updated for greater flexibility and alignment with government platforms like URA's EDA and BCA's eSS.  This specific document copy was downloaded under a single-user license by CHANG KUO WEI/MR of CH2M HILL SINGAPORE PTE LTD in 2019 via the Singapore Standards eShop.

elements.summary: CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) is a Singaporean Code of Practice for CAD Layer Names, aiming to standardize CAD layer usage across the Architecture, Engineering, and Construction (AEC) industry.  Developed with input from various organizations including government agencies (URA, BCA) and professional bodies, it's used for electronic submissions like EDA and eSS.  This revised version streamlines practices for both building and infrastructure projects, offering flexibility in combining main and sub-elements within the defined naming convention (detailed in the code's tables and figures). Key updates include expanded element lists and alignment with industry software tools supported by BCA training.  The document includes clauses defining scope, purpose, and definitions, along with examples and annexes listing main and sub-elements.  It's licensed by Enterprise Singapore for single-user use only.

It explains that the standard, focusing on CAD layer names, was created by a technical committee and references other publications.  Key updates streamline CAD practices across building and infrastructure projects, offering users more flexibility in combining main and sub-elements.  The foreword also notes the standard's adoption by various organizations like URA and BCA for electronic submissions, alongside supporting software tools and training initiatives. Finally, it includes a disclaimer regarding potential patent rights associated with some elements within the standard.

elements.text: Current users of CP 83 include architects, professional engineers - C&S and M&E, as well as contractorswho participate in Electronic Submission. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and the BuildingConstruction Authority (BCA) have adopted the CAD layers for Electronic Development Application (EDA)and Electronic Submission System (eSS) respectively.
elements.summary: CP 83, a Singapore Standard for CAD layer organization, is used by architects, civil/structural & mechanical/electrical engineers, and contractors involved in Electronic Submission.  Government agencies like the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Building Construction Authority (BCA) have also adopted it for their respective electronic submission systems (EDA and eSS).

elements.text: CAD vendors have developed software tools that can implement and support CP 83. BCA has beenconducting hands-on training on CP 83 and the software application on various CAD platforms.
elements.summary: Software tools supporting the CP 83 CAD layering standard have been developed, and the Building Construction Authority (BCA) provides training on CP 83 implementation across various CAD platforms.

elements.text: The revision of CP 83: Part 1 CAD layer names, is required in order to streamline industry practices forbuilding projects as well as infrastructure projects such as the Mass Rapid Transport extensions whichinclude architectural, civil and structural as well as mechanical and electrical works. The revised list ofmain and sub elements gives the users flexibility to combine the main and sub-elements based ontheir requirements.

The text also notes that CAD vendors have developed tools supporting CP 83, and BCA provides training on its implementation.

The key concept illustrated is the standardization of CAD layer naming.  This revision streamlines industry practices for both building and infrastructure projects, encompassing architectural, civil, structural, mechanical, and electrical works.  The standard aims to improve interoperability and data exchange between different stakeholders involved in construction projects in Singapore.  A cautionary note regarding potential patent rights related to elements within the standard is also included.

elements.text: Attention is drawn to the possibility that some of the elements of this Singapore Standard may be thesubject of patent rights. Enterprise Singapore shall not be held responsible for identifying any or all ofsuch patent rights.

It's used by architects, engineers, and contractors, and adopted by URA and BCA for electronic submissions.  Key revisions streamline practices across building and infrastructure projects, offering users flexibility in combining main and sub-element layers. pages.summary: Singapore Standard CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) is a Code of Practice for CAD layer naming, aiming to standardize CAD usage across the AEC industry for both building and infrastructure projects.  Developed collaboratively with industry and government agencies (URA, BCA), it's used for electronic submissions (EDA, eSS).  Key revisions provide flexibility in combining main and sub-elements within a defined six-field naming convention (Originator, Classification, Presentation, Status, User Defined, View), detailed in tables and figures within the document.  Software tools supporting CP 83 are available, and BCA offers training.  The standard is licensed by Enterprise Singapore for single-user use and includes a disclaimer regarding potential patent rights.

elements.text: C ode of practice for construction computer-aided design (CAD)Part 1 – Organisation and naming of CAD layers
elements.summary: This Singapore Standard (CP 83 Part 1) defines a code of practice for organizing and naming CAD layers within construction projects.  It aims to standardize CAD layer usage across the Singaporean construction industry, facilitating better communication and management of CAD data among architects, engineers, contractors, and regulatory bodies like URA and BCA.  The standard establishes general principles for layer structure, provides a list of standard layer element names, and is applicable to all parties involved in creating and using CAD documentation.  Software developers are expected to support this standard within their CAD tools.  This revised version streamlines practices for both building and infrastructure projects and offers users flexibility in combining main and sub-layer elements.

elements.text: 1 Scope
elements.summary: This excerpt from Singapore Standard CP 83 Part 1 details the scope of the code of practice for construction computer-aided design (CAD).  It defines the standard's purpose as establishing uniform CAD layer organization and naming conventions for the Singapore construction industry.  This standardization aims to improve communication and management of CAD data across different project stakeholders, including architects, engineers, contractors, and government agencies like URA and BCA.  The standard applies to all parties involved in creating and using CAD documentation, including software developers who are expected to support these conventions.  The standard also addresses the structuring of data within component libraries.

elements.text: T his Singapore Standard establishes the general principles of layer structure within constructioncomputer-aided design (CAD) files. It covers the organisation and allocation of layers that are used inCAD files for construction projects, and is intended to be used for communication and managementpurposes. A list of standard CAD layer element names is provided in this code.
elements.summary: This Singapore Standard defines principles for organizing CAD layers within construction project files.  It specifies how layers should be structured and assigned to facilitate communication and management, and provides a standardized list of CAD layer element names.

elements.text: T he principles established in this code are applicable to all parties involved in preparing and usingtechnical documentation on CAD systems. Although these principles are primarily for users, CADsystem developers are expected to provide software tools capable of implementing and supporting thiscode. An important use is also to structure data in component libraries produced by third parties.
elements.summary: This section of the Singapore Standard for construction CAD details the applicability of the code.  It emphasizes that while primarily for CAD users, software developers should ensure their systems support the code's implementation, including third-party component libraries.  The code applies to all parties involved in creating and using CAD-based technical documentation.

elements.text: 2 Purpose
elements.summary: The purpose of the Singapore Standard Code of Practice for Construction Computer-Aided Design (CAD) Part 1 is to establish a uniform system for organizing and naming CAD layers within the Singapore construction industry. This standardization aims to improve communication and management of CAD data across all project stakeholders.

elements.text: T he purpose of this code is to establish uniformity in the organisation and naming of CAD layers forthe construction industry in Singapore.
elements.summary: This Singaporean code of practice aims to standardize CAD layer organization and naming within the construction industry, promoting consistent practices for improved communication and management of CAD data.

elements.text: 3 Definitions
elements.summary: This section of the Singapore Standard defines key terms related to CAD layer structure.  It defines "Layer" as an organizational attribute in CAD files used for data separation, management, communication, and visibility control, noting that synonyms like "level" may be used.  It also indicates that a definition for "CAD model" will follow.

elements.text: F or the purposes of this code, the following definitions shall apply.
elements.summary: This section of the Singapore Standard specifies that the definitions provided within the standard document will be used for interpreting and applying the code related to CAD layer structure.  In other words, the document establishes its own internal glossary of terms for clarity and consistency.

elements.text: 3 .1 Layer
elements.summary: This excerpt defines a "Layer" within Computer-Aided Design (CAD) systems as an organizational tool for managing and communicating data, controlling visibility on screen and in printed drawings.  It clarifies that other terms like "level" may be used synonymously within different CAD software.  The definition emphasizes the layer's role in separating data within CAD files.

elements.text: O rganisational attribute of entities in CAD files, used to separate data in order to manage andcommunicate those data, to control visibility on the computer screen and on plotted drawings.
elements.summary: This excerpt defines a CAD layer as an organizational tool within CAD files.  Layers separate data for management, communication, and control of visibility both on-screen and in printed drawings.  It also notes that other terms, like "level," may be used synonymously with "layer" in various CAD systems.

elements.text: N OTE – In CAD systems, synonyms for “layer” are used, for example “level.”
elements.summary: Some CAD systems use synonyms for "layer," such as "level."  This is important to note given the code's goal of standardizing CAD layer organization and naming.

elements.text: 3 .2 CAD model
elements.summary: A CAD model is a structured CAD file organized according to the physical parts of the object it represents (e.g., a building or mechanical device).  Models can be 2D or 3D and contain both graphical and non-graphical data.

elements.text: S tructured CAD data file(s) organised according to the physical parts of the objects represented, forexample, a building or a mechanical device.
elements.summary: CAD data files are structured and organized based on the physical components of the represented objects, such as buildings or mechanical devices.

elements.text: N OTE – Models can be two-dimensional or three-dimensional, and can include graphical as well as non-graphical data attached to the objects.
elements.summary: CAD models can be 2D or 3D, containing both graphical and non-graphical data linked to the model's objects.  This expands on the prior definitions of CAD model, drawing, and plot, clarifying that models aren't limited to visual representation.

elements.text: 3 .3 CAD drawing
elements.summary: A CAD drawing (3.3) is a selected portion of a CAD model, displayed on screen or paper.  Visibility is controlled through views and layers.  Drawings may include additional graphics like borderlines and title blocks, and can be created with or without an underlying CAD model (drawing-oriented vs. model-oriented approach).

elements.text: S elected parts of a CAD model as presented on screen or on paper.
elements.summary: A CAD view shows selected portions of a CAD model, either on-screen or printed.

elements.text: N OTE – Visibility on the drawing can be controlled by views and layers. The drawing can contain additionalgraphics, such as borderlines, title-block and legends. CAD drawings can also be produced independentlywithout an underlying CAD model (a drawing-oriented approach as opposed to the model-oriented approach).
elements.summary: CAD drawings display selected portions of a CAD model, potentially with added graphics like borders and title blocks.  Visibility within a drawing is managed through views and layers.  While drawings are often derived from models (model-oriented approach), they can also be created independently (drawing-oriented approach).

elements.text: 3 .4 Plot
elements.summary: Given the provided context of CAD models, drawings, and related terms, the single term "3.4 Plot" likely refers to a hardcopy or electronic output of a CAD drawing, generated from either a 2D or 3D model or created independently.  This output could be to various media (paper or electronic) and would represent the selected elements visible based on active views and layers.  It's analogous to the "print" function in many CAD applications.

elements.text: G raphic image created by a numerically controlled draughting machine and presented on draughtingmedia.
elements.summary: A plot is a graphic image created by a numerically controlled drafting machine and presented on a drafting medium.  This relates to the broader context of CAD models and drawings, which can be 2D or 3D, and may exist with or without underlying model data.

pages.summary: This document details Singapore Standard CP 83 Part 1, a code of practice for construction computer-aided design (CAD).  It establishes a uniform system for organizing and naming CAD layers within the Singapore construction industry to improve communication and data management across all stakeholders (architects, engineers, contractors, government agencies, and software developers).  The standard defines key terms like "Layer" (an organizational attribute for data separation and visibility control, sometimes called "level"), "CAD model" (a structured file representing a physical object), "Drawing" (a selected portion of a model displayed on screen or paper), and "Plot" (a hardcopy or electronic output of a drawing).  CP 83 applies to all parties involved in creating and using CAD documentation, requiring software developers to support the standard.  A single-user license for this standard was purchased by CHANG KUO WEI/MR of CH2M HILL SINGAPORE PTE LTD on August 29, 2019, with restrictions on copying and networking.

elements.summary: This excerpt from CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines several terms related to CAD drawings and layering.  It clarifies that a CAD drawing (3.3) can be derived from a model or created independently.  A plot (3.4) is a physical output from a plotter.  A wildcard (3.5) is a character used for flexible string comparisons.  Finally, it introduces the concept of layer name sub-classification (3.6) with multiple independent classifications possible, starting with "Originator" (3.6.1).  The standard emphasizes the control over drawing visibility through views and layers.

elements.text: 3.5 Wildcard
elements.summary: A wildcard is a special character used in string comparisons to match any character or group of characters.  This functionality is relevant within the context of CAD drawings and models, potentially for searching or filtering layer names, file names, or other text-based data.

elements.text: A special character used to match any character or group of characters in a string comparison.
elements.summary: Wildcards are special characters used in string comparisons to represent any character or group of characters.

elements.text: 3 .6 Layer name sub-classification
elements.summary: The text defines the sub-classification of CAD layer names, using independent classifications for originator (individual/company/organization responsible for the layer's creation) and element (a two-level classification of construction work/system with main element and sub-element).

elements.text: T he following concepts are used in the layer name. An independent classification can be applied toeach concept.
elements.summary: CAD layer names utilize independent classifications for each of the following concepts: Originator (individual/company/organization creating the layer), Element (classified construction work/system with main and sub-element levels), and potentially Wildcard characters (for string comparison matching).

elements.text: 3 .6.1 Originator
elements.summary: This section (3.6.1 Originator) of CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines the "Originator" within the layer naming convention as the individual, company, or organization responsible for creating and preparing the information on that specific CAD layer.

elements.text: T he originator refers to the individual/company/organisation responsible for preparation and creation ofinformation on the CAD layer.
elements.summary: The "originator" in a CAD layer name identifies the individual, company, or organization responsible for creating and preparing the information on that layer.

elements.text: 3 .6.2 Element
elements.summary: Section 3.6.2 defines an "Element" within a CAD layer naming convention.  An Element classifies construction work or a system using two sub-classifications: "Main Element" (primary system/work type) and "Sub-element" (specific subsystem within the main element).

elements.text: A n element is a classified construction work or system. It consists of two levels of classifications,namely, main element and sub-element.
elements.summary: Elements within CAD layers are classified construction works or systems, categorized hierarchically into two levels: main element and sub-element.

elements.text: 3 .6.3 Main element
elements.summary: Main element is the primary classification level within the "Element" concept used in CAD layer naming. It categorizes the main types of construction work or building systems.

elements.text: M ain element is the first level of element classification. It represents the different types of mainconstruction works or systems.
elements.summary: Main elements are the primary classification level for construction works or systems in CAD layering.  They represent the major categories of elements within a project.

elements.text: 3 .6.4 Sub-element
elements.summary: Sub-elements provide a second level of classification within a main element, representing the various sub-systems of that main construction work or system.

elements.text: S ub-element is the second level of element classification. It represents the various sub-systemswithin the main element.
elements.summary: Sub-elements provide a further level of classification within main elements, representing the different sub-systems of a larger construction work or system.  This allows for more granular categorization of elements in CAD drawings.

elements.text: 3 .6.5 Presentation
elements.summary: Presentation in CAD drawings refers to the format and visual appearance of information on screen and paper, distinct from element information which describes the construction work or system itself.

elements.text: P resentation is the format or type of information presented in CAD drawings. It is related primarily tothe graphic appearance on screen and paper, as against element information, which is related toconstruction work or system.
elements.summary: CAD drawing "Presentation" refers to the graphic format and appearance of information on screen and paper, differentiating it from "element information" which describes the actual construction work or system.

elements.text: 3 .6.6 Status
elements.summary: "Status" in AEC documentation, specifically within the context of addition-and-alteration works, defines the condition of an element as being new, retained from existing construction, or slated for demolition.

elements.text: S tatus defines whether the element in addition-and-alteration works is new, for retention or demolition etc.
elements.summary: In CAD documentation for addition and alteration projects, the "Status" attribute of an element defines whether that element is new, existing to be retained, or slated for demolition.

elements.text: 3 .6.7 User-defined
elements.summary: "User-defined" fields provide a flexible way to add customized information to CAD elements, allowing users to further categorize elements beyond the standard classifications (like sub-element, presentation, and status) or add descriptive details not otherwise captured within the system. This enhances the organization and management of CAD data, particularly useful when transferring data between different systems and organizations.

elements.text: U ser-defined is an additional information field, which the user may wish to use for further subdivisionof layers or provide a description not covered under this Singapore Standard.
elements.summary: User-defined fields in CAD layering provide flexibility beyond the standard classifications outlined in the Singapore Standard, allowing users to add custom subdivisions or descriptions to layers as needed.

elements.text: 4 Concepts, format and codes used in construction documentation
elements.summary: This section of the Singapore Standard outlines the concepts, formats, and codes for CAD layering in construction projects.  Consistent layering facilitates interoperability between different CAD systems and organizations, enabling efficient data exchange and management.  Project stakeholders must agree upon layer selection, codes, and data transfer methods.  The standard promotes structured layering using classifications for clear communication, management, and submission to approving agencies.

elements.text: 4 .1 General
elements.summary: This section (4.1 General) introduces the concepts, format, and codes for CAD layering in construction projects.  Consistent layer naming conventions are crucial for interoperability and data management across different systems and organizations.  The standard proposes a structured layer naming system using a fixed character length and reserved codes for consistent identification and selection. Project stakeholders should agree upon layer usage and data exchange protocols.  Layer names should be both human- and machine-readable.

elements.text: W hen CAD data is transferred between different systems and organisations, their structure needs tobe understood for identification of the source of the CAD data, selection to suit the needs of differentspecialists and management of the data.
elements.summary: When transferring CAD data between different systems and organizations, understanding the data structure is crucial for identifying its source, enabling specialists to select relevant information, and facilitating effective data management.

elements.text: L ayering is a commonly used technique to achieve such an organisation of CAD data. Layers aregiven unique names so that they can be selectively viewed and plotted. CAD layers need to bestructured based on clear and logical organisation of information that fulfils the functional requirementsof the information users. The organisation of these information can be achieved through the use ofclassifications of information in different parts of the layer name.
elements.summary: CAD data is organized using layers with unique names for selective viewing and plotting.  Effective layering requires a clear, logical structure based on information classification within the layer name to meet user needs.

pages.summary: CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines standards for CAD layering and drawing management in construction projects, emphasizing interoperability and clear communication.  The standard details a structured layer naming convention incorporating classifications for Originator (individual/company responsible), Element (hierarchical classification of construction work/system with main and sub-elements), Presentation (visual appearance), and Status (new, existing, demolished).  It also allows for User-defined fields for added flexibility.  Key terms defined include CAD drawing, plot, and wildcard (for string comparisons).  Consistent layer naming, including the use of codes and agreed-upon data transfer methods, is crucial for efficient data exchange and management between different CAD systems and organizations, especially in addition-and-alteration projects.  This structured approach facilitates clear identification, selection, and control of drawing visibility through views and layers, ultimately supporting effective project management and submission to approving agencies.

elements.text: The following concepts, categories, format and codes shall be used to allocate layers on constructionprojects for the purposes of communication, management and submission to approving agencies. Thoseinvolved in any project shall agree on the selection of the layers and codes to be used and how the datawill be transferred between their CAD systems.
elements.summary: Construction project CAD layering must follow agreed-upon concepts, categories, formats, and codes for communication, management, and submission purposes.  Project stakeholders must pre-determine layer selection, codes, and CAD system data transfer methods.

elements.text: A ll characters used in the layer names shall be both human- and machine-readable whereverpossible. A layer format with fixed number of characters is used to allow selection of layers by the useof wildcard. Where reserved codes are given, they shall be used only for the purpose specified. Otherproject-specific codes may also be used.
elements.summary: CAD layer names should use human- and machine-readable characters in a fixed-length format to enable wildcard selection.  Reserved codes must be used as specified, while project-specific codes are also permitted.  This standardized format facilitates data exchange and management across different systems and organizations.

elements.text: L ayer names are divided into fields. Each field holds one concept. Fields are either mandatory oroptional. Mandatory fields shall always be included in the layer names. Optional fields can be used asrequired in each project. The order of fields in a layer name and the number of characters for eachfield shall be maintained as defined in this code unless an alternative is specifically agreed by theproject partners. However, the alternative adopted shall be documented in a way that future retrievalof the layer-structured information can be ensured.
elements.summary: CAD layer names are structured with mandatory and optional fields, each representing a specific concept.  The defined order and character length of these fields must be maintained unless an alternative, documented for future retrieval, is agreed upon by project partners.

elements.text: 4 .2 Format of layer name
elements.summary: Section 4.2 details the required format for CAD layer names to ensure consistent data exchange and management across different systems and organizations.  Layer names are structured using five fields: originator, element, system, detail, and user-defined.  The first two (originator and element) are mandatory, while the remaining three are optional and project-specific.  Underscores separate each field for readability.  A fixed character length for each field facilitates layer selection using wildcards.  While the standard format should be followed, project partners can agree on alternatives, provided they document these changes for future data retrieval.

elements.text: A layer name consists of the following five fields as shown in Table 1.
elements.summary: This text excerpt from CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015), a Singapore Standard, defines the format of CAD layer names for construction projects.  Layer names are structured for consistent data exchange and management across different systems and organizations.  The standard mandates a five-field structure (detailed in Table 1, not provided here) with mandatory fields for originator and element, and optional fields for system, detail, and user-defined information. Underscores separate the fields.  Project partners must agree on layer usage and coding conventions, documenting any deviations from the standard.  This structured approach ensures clear communication, management, and submission of CAD data to approving agencies.

elements.text: Table 1 – Description of fields in a layer name
elements.summary: The text describes the structure of CAD layer names for construction documentation, emphasizing consistent formatting for interoperability and data management.  Layer names are divided into five fields (some optional): originator, element, system, detail, and status.  Underscores separate fields, and hyphens fill unused character spaces within a field.  The originator and element fields are mandatory.  Project partners must agree on layer usage and document any deviations from the standard format.  This structured approach facilitates data exchange, selection, and management across different systems and organizations.

elements.summary:
This image and text excerpt from CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015), a Singapore standard, describes the layer naming convention for CAD data used in construction projects. The image, Figure 1, visually represents the layer name format, which is divided into five fields: Originator, Element, Status, Detail, and Revision.  These fields are separated by underscores "_" for readability.

The accompanying text details the coding conventions for these fields.  The Originator and Element fields are mandatory and must always be present. Optional fields (Status, Detail, and Revision) are marked with an asterisk "*" in Figure 1 and can be used as needed within a project.  If an optional field is not used, hyphens "-" fill the remaining character spaces within that field.  All fields are left-justified.

The standard specifies that all characters in the layer name must be both human- and machine-readable. A fixed number of characters for each field is recommended to facilitate layer selection using wildcards.  Allowed characters are A-Z, 0-9, hyphen "-", and underscore "_".  The specific number of characters per field is not provided in this excerpt.

The key concept is structured layering for effective CAD data management.  This standardized format allows for consistent communication, management, and submission of CAD data to approving agencies.  The text emphasizes the importance of project partners agreeing upon the selected layers and codes and documenting any deviations from the standard format to ensure future retrieval of information.  The standard aims to improve interoperability and data exchange between different CAD systems used in construction projects.

elements.text: Figure 1 – Layer name format
elements.summary: The text describes the prescribed format for CAD layer names according to CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015).  Layer names use a fixed-length, human- and machine-readable format for interoperability between project partners.  The format consists of five fields: originator, element (both mandatory), and optional fields for discipline, buildability status, and additional information.  Fields are separated by underscores, unused characters within mandatory fields are filled with hyphens, and unused optional fields can be omitted.  "Figure 1" (not provided) visually depicts this structure.  Project teams must agree upon and document any deviations from this standard.

elements.text: (NOTE: * - Optional field)
elements.summary: This text defines a standardized layer naming convention for CAD systems in AEC projects.  Layer names use a five-field structure: Originator, Element, View, Status, and Detail (*Optional).  Fields are separated by underscores, unused characters within mandatory fields are filled with hyphens, and unused optional fields can be omitted.  All project partners must agree upon the selected layers and codes, documenting any deviations from the standard.  The format ensures human and machine readability for communication, management, and submission to approving agencies.  The allowed characters are A-Z, 0-9, hyphen, and underscore.  All fields are left-justified.  The Originator and Element fields are mandatory.

elements.text: 4 .3 Coding conventions
elements.summary: Layer names must be human- and machine-readable using a fixed-length format with mandatory (originator, element) and optional fields, separated by underscores.  Hyphens fill unused characters within a field.  Allowed characters are A-Z, 0-9, hyphen, and underscore.  Fields are left-justified, and unused optional fields can be omitted.  Reserved codes must be used as specified, and any project-specific deviations must be documented to ensure future retrieval of layer information.

elements.text: 4 .3.1 The first two fields, namely originator and element shall always be used.
elements.summary: Layer names are structured with mandatory and optional fields, separated by underscores.  The "originator" and "element" fields are mandatory and always used.  While character limits and field order are defined, project partners can agree on alternatives if documented for future retrieval.  Allowed characters are A-Z, 0-9, hyphen, and underscore. Unused characters in mandatory fields are filled with hyphens, while optional fields can be omitted if unused.

elements.text: 4 .3.2 The underscore character “_” is used between fields to enhance readability.
elements.summary: CAD layer names use a five-field format (originator, element, etc.) separated by underscores for readability.  The originator and element fields are mandatory.  Unused trailing characters within mandatory fields are filled with hyphens. Optional fields can be omitted.

pages.summary: Singapore Standard CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines a standardized, five-field CAD layer naming convention for construction projects to improve interoperability and data management.  The mandatory "originator" and "element" fields, along with optional fields (variations include system/component, detail/phase, status, material, buildability status, view, revision, additional information, and user-defined), are separated by underscores.  A fixed-length format using alphanumeric characters, hyphens (as placeholders in mandatory fields), and underscores ensures both human and machine readability.  While adherence to the standard format is encouraged, project partners can agree upon and document deviations for future reference.  This structured approach facilitates consistent data exchange, selection, and management across different CAD systems and organizations, streamlining communication and submission to approving agencies.

elements.summary: The provided text "CP 83 : Part 1 : 2004 (2015)" refers to a specific standard (likely a British Standard Code of Practice) for layer naming conventions within the AEC industry.  The accompanying context details the rules defined in this standard.  Key aspects include a mandatory originator and element field, followed by optional fields. Underscores separate fields, hyphens denote no further subdivision within a field and fill unused trailing characters in mandatory fields.  Allowed characters are alphanumeric, hyphens, and underscores.  Fields are left-justified, and unused trailing *optional* fields can be omitted.

elements.text: 4.3.3 For indication of no further subdivision of the information, hyphens shall be used to fill out tothe end of the field.
elements.summary: Within the layer naming convention, if a field has no further subdivisions, it should be filled with hyphens ("-") to the end of the field.

elements.text: 4 .3.4 Alphanumeric characters allowed are the letters A - Z, the digits 0 - 9, in addition to thehyphen and underscore characters.
elements.summary: Layer names use alphanumeric characters (A-Z, 0-9), hyphens (-), and underscores (_).

elements.text: 4 .3.5 All fields are left justified.
elements.summary: Layer names are left-justified within their fields.

elements.text: 4 .3.6 Unused trailing characters in a mandatory field shall be represented by the hyphen "-"character.
elements.summary: Within the layer naming convention, any unused characters in a *required* field must be filled with hyphens ("-").

elements.text: 4 .3.7 Unused trailing fields in optional part of the layer name can be omitted.
elements.summary: Unused trailing fields within the optional part of a CAD layer name, as defined in CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015), can be omitted.  This contrasts with mandatory fields which must be filled with hyphens if unused (4.3.6).

elements.text: 4 .4 Layer name fields
elements.summary: Layer names are structured with specific fields.  These fields are left-justified and unused trailing characters in mandatory fields are filled with hyphens. Optional fields can be omitted.  A two-character originator field identifies the discipline responsible for the layer's creation, with the first character (a capital letter) representing the discipline according to Table 2.

elements.text: 4 .4.1 Originator field
elements.summary: The Originator field, a two-character code, identifies the discipline responsible for the CAD layer's information.  The first character (capital letter) broadly defines the discipline (e.g., "A" for Architect, "S" for Structural Engineer – see Table 2 for full list). The second character provides further detail, like a sub-discipline (e.g., "L" in "AL" for Landscape Architect) or differentiates multiple entities within the same discipline (e.g., "A1" and "A2" for two different architects).  If no further specification is needed, a hyphen ("-") is used as the second character (e.g., "A-" for a general Architect).  Organizations can internally define additional codes beyond Table 2.

elements.text: T his field indicates the discipline of an individual/company/organisation responsible for the preparationand creation of information in the CAD layer. Since there is a multitude of possible classifications,depending on the type and organisation of the project at hand, two (2) alphanumeric characters areused for this field.
elements.summary: The "originator" field in CAD layer names identifies the discipline responsible for creating the layer's information.  It uses two alphanumeric characters to accommodate diverse project classifications and organizational structures.

elements.text: T his first character is a single alphabet code in capital letter to abbreviate the discipline of theoriginator of the layer. The list of possible originator codes is as shown in Table 2.

elements.summary:
The provided text and absent image describe the originator field specification within a CAD layer standard, likely derived from a Singapore standard document licensed by Enterprise Singapore. This field identifies the individual, company, or organization responsible for creating the information on that layer.  The originator field consists of two alphanumeric characters.

The *first character* is a single capital letter representing the discipline of the originator (e.g., 'A' for Architect, 'S' for Structural Engineer).  Table 2, not included in the provided text, lists these codes. The text mentions that organizations can use additional codes internally for disciplines not listed in the standard table.

The *second character* further defines the originator. It can be:

* **A hyphen '-':** Used if the first character sufficiently identifies the originator (e.g., "A-" for Architect, "S-" for Structural Engineer).
* **A letter:**  Used to specify a sub-discipline. The example given is "AL" for Landscape Architect.
* **A number:** Used to differentiate multiple originators from the same discipline working on the same project (e.g., "A1" and "A2" for two different architects).

The standard aims to provide a consistent and organized way to track the source of information within CAD drawings, facilitating collaboration and information management across disciplines.  The flexibility of the second character allows for adaptation to various project structures and organizational needs.

elements.text: Additional originator codes may be used internally within an organisation or project to denote otherdisciplines not included in Table 2.
elements.summary: While Table 2 provides standard originator codes for CAD layers, organizations and projects can use additional codes internally for disciplines not listed in the table.

pages.summary: CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines a CAD layer naming standard for the AEC industry.  Layer names follow a structured format with mandatory originator and element fields, followed by optional fields, separated by underscores.  The two-character originator field identifies the discipline responsible for the layer. The first character (capital letter) represents the discipline (e.g., "A" for Architect), while the second character allows for sub-discipline or individual identification (e.g., "AL" for Landscape Architect, "A1" for Architect 1).  A hyphen ("-") fills unused trailing characters in *mandatory* fields or serves as the second character in the originator field if no further specification is needed.  *Optional* trailing fields can be omitted.  Allowed characters are alphanumeric, hyphens, and underscores. All fields are left-justified.  While Table 2 provides standard originator codes, organizations can define additional codes internally.

elements.text: 4.4.1.2 Second character
elements.summary:
The second character of the Originator field in CAD layer names further defines the discipline.  It can be:

* **A letter:**  Used to specify a sub-discipline (e.g., "AL" for Landscape Architect).
* **A hyphen ("-"):** Used if the first character sufficiently defines the discipline (e.g., "A-" for Architect).
* **A number:** Used to differentiate multiple originators from the same discipline within the same project (e.g., "A1" and "A2" for two different architects).

elements.text: T he second character provides further definition of the originator whenever necessary. Example: ALto denote Landscape Architect. If the first character is sufficient to define the originator of the layer, ahyphen "-" shall be used as the second character of this field. Example: A- for architect and S- forstructural engineer.
elements.summary: The second character in the originator field provides further disciplinary distinction when needed (e.g., "AL" for Landscape Architect).  If no further distinction is required, a hyphen "-" is used as the second character (e.g., "A-" for Architect, "S-" for Structural Engineer).

elements.text: T his second alphanumeric character can also be used to denote different originators from the samediscipline involved in the same project. Example: A1 and A2 represent two different architects workingon the same project.
elements.summary: The second character of the two-character originator code can differentiate between multiple entities from the same discipline working on the same project. For example, A1 and A2 could represent two different architectural firms.

elements.text: 4 .4.2 Element field
elements.summary: The "Element field" uses an eight-character code to classify construction elements.  The first four characters represent the mandatory "Main element," defining the primary system or work type.  The following four characters are the optional "Sub-element," providing further classification only when needed; otherwise, it's filled with "----".

elements.text: T his field indicates the type of construction work or system of the element in the layer. Classificationfor the construction elements or systems is in the form of eight (8) letters of the alphabet. Thiselement field has two levels of classification, namely, the main and sub-elements.
elements.summary: This text describes the "element field" used in classifying layers within a construction project.  This eight-character code identifies the type of construction work or system.  It's divided into two four-character segments: the "main element" (mandatory) and the "sub-element" (optional, use "----" if not needed), providing a hierarchical system for element classification.

elements.text: 4 .4.2.1 Main element
elements.summary: Layer names use a coded system.  The "Main Element" field, a mandatory four-letter code, identifies the primary construction work or system of the element within the layer.

elements.text: T he main element consists of four (4) letters of the alphabet and is mandatory. It identifies the mainconstruction work or system of the element.
elements.summary: The main element, a mandatory four-letter alphabetic code, identifies the primary construction work or system of a building element.

elements.text: 4 .4.2.2 Sub-element
elements.summary: Sub-elements, a further classification of the main element within a layer's element field, consist of four characters.  While optional, they provide more specific detail when the main element is insufficient. If not used, the sub-element field is filled with "----".  Recommended sub-element names are listed in Annex B, grouped under their respective main elements.  For consistency, users should utilize these provided names where applicable.  User-defined sub-elements are permitted for internal use but must be documented and communicated clearly within the project team.  While no strict rules exist for creating these custom abbreviations, a general guideline is to truncate vowels while retaining the first and last characters.

elements.text: T he sub-element consists of four (4) letters of the alphabet and is only used for further classification ofthe main element. For elements where classification using the main element is sufficient, the sub-element may be coded with four (4) hyphen characters "- - - -".
elements.summary: Sub-elements, using four characters, provide further classification of main elements within the coding system.  If the main element provides sufficient classification, the sub-element field is filled with "----".

pages.summary: This excerpt from Singapore Standard CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015), licensed by Enterprise Singapore, details CAD layer naming conventions, specifically the "Element field" and "Originator" field.  The Element field uses an eight-character code: a mandatory four-character "Main Element" (e.g., "SLAB") and an optional four-character "Sub-element" ("----" if unused).  Standard Main Element names are listed in Annex A, and recommended Sub-element names are in Annex B, grouped by Main Element.  While user-defined elements are allowed for internal use, they must be documented and communicated within the project team.  The Originator field's second character further specifies the discipline using a letter for sub-disciplines (e.g., "AL"), a hyphen if the first character suffices (e.g., "A-"), or a number to differentiate multiple entities within the same discipline (e.g., "A1", "A2").  Table 3 (not shown) provides classification examples.  Consistency through the use of standard names is emphasized.  The document reinforces the single-user license restriction.

The context excerpt describes the coding structure within the standard for classifying construction elements and their presentation format.

CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines a coding system for construction elements.  A mandatory four-letter code identifies the main element, with an optional four-letter sub-element code for further classification (or "----" if not used).  Standard main element names are listed in Annex A, and recommended sub-element names in Annex B, promoting industry consistency.  User-defined elements are permitted but require documentation.  A presentation field, using one or two alphanumeric characters, defines the format of the information.  The first character broadly classifies information as graphics, annotations, models, or paper/page information, with further sub-classification possible (e.g., annotation types, paper/page elements). Table 3 and Table 4 provide examples and valid codes respectively.

It has two levels: a basic classification (element graphics, annotation, model, or paper/page information) and a further classification, which currently only applies to annotations (text, hatching, dimension, and marking).

elements.summary:
This text and image excerpt from a Singaporean engineering standard (SS) details the naming conventions for layers in digital engineering drawings, specifically focusing on those used in addition and alteration (A&A) works.  The image, Figure 2, provides a visual example of this layer naming structure.

**Image Content:** Figure 2 depicts a simple diagram illustrating the structure of a layer name:  `A-WALLPARP-E-N`.  It's broken down into four fields separated by hyphens.  The diagram uses color-coding and annotations to explain each field.

**Technical Specifications:** The document specifies the codes for each field in the layer name.  The first character of the "Presentation" field (third field in the example) is defined in Table 4 (not shown in the excerpt but referenced).  For element graphics, the second character of the "Presentation" field represents the projection/view as detailed in Table 5 (also not shown). The "Status" field (fourth field) uses a single character code from Table 6 (not shown).  The excerpt mentions "TL" as a possible code for the "Presentation" field if Text and Title are on separate layers.

**Code or Standard Reference:** The document explicitly refers to a Singapore Standard (SS) and includes licensing information from Enterprise Singapore.  The order number (6800055693) and download date (2019-08-29) are also provided, indicating the specific version of the standard.  Sections 4.4.3.2, 4.4.4, and 4.4.5 are mentioned, relating to the second character of the presentation field, the status field, and the user-defined field, respectively.

**Key Concepts:** The standard aims to establish a consistent and unambiguous layer naming system for A&A drawings.  The structure facilitates organization and communication between different parties involved in a project. The example, `A-WALLPARP-E-N`, demonstrates the following:

* **Originator Code (A-):**  "A" represents the Architect who created the layer.
* **Element Name (WALLPARP):** "WALLPARP" identifies the element as a parapet wall ("WALL") with "PARP" likely being a sub-element or specific type.
* **Presentation (E-):** "E" indicates that the layer contains element graphics.
* **Status (N):** "N" denotes that the wall is "New Work."

The standard also allows for a user-defined field for further customization, though it stresses the importance of documenting and communicating the meaning of any user-defined codes.

elements.summary:
This text and image excerpt from CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015), a Singapore standard, describes the naming convention for layers in architectural and engineering drawings.  The image, Figure 2, provides a visual example of this layer naming structure.

**Image Content:** Figure 2 depicts a diagram breaking down a sample layer name: `A-WALLPARP-E-N`. Each part of the name is color-coded and corresponds to a specific field.  The fields illustrated are Originator, Element, Presentation, and Status.

**Technical Specifications:** The diagram itself doesn't contain numerical values or measurements. However, the accompanying text refers to Tables 5 and 6, which define single-character codes for the Presentation and Status fields, respectively.  Table 5 specifies codes for different projection/views (e.g., plan, elevation, section), while Table 6 defines codes for statuses like "new work," "existing," "to be demolished," etc.  The text emphasizes that the Status field is optional.

**Code or Standard Reference:** The document explicitly references "CP 83 : Part 1 : 2004 (2015)."  This likely refers to a specific part of the Singapore Standard Code of Practice for architectural and engineering drawings.

**Key Concepts:** The core concept is a standardized layer naming system for CAD drawings to facilitate clear communication and collaboration between different parties involved in a project (e.g., architects, engineers, contractors). The system uses a structured, coded approach, with each field in the layer name providing specific information about the layer's contents and purpose.  The example highlights the Originator (A- for Architect), Element (WALLPARP for parapet wall), Presentation (E- for element graphics), and Status (N for new work).  The text also mentions a user-defined field for additional flexibility, provided its usage is documented and communicated effectively.  The document provides further examples like `A-_WALL----_E-` to reinforce the structure and usage of the naming convention.

elements.text: 4 .4.5 User-defined field
elements.summary: The "User-defined field" (4.4.5) within the Singapore Standard CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) for CAD layering in AEC projects allows for flexibility beyond the standard Originator, Element, Presentation, and Status fields.  While not mandatory, it enables additional information or further layer subdivision.  Crucially, any use of this field requires clear documentation and communication among project stakeholders.

elements.text: 5 Examples of layer name structure
elements.summary: The provided text states there are "5 Examples of layer name structure," but only provides three, illustrating how to structure CAD layer names according to CP 83 : Part 1 : 2004 (2015).  The examples demonstrate the use of Originator (e.g., A- for architect), Element (e.g., WALLPARP for parapet wall), Presentation (e.g., E- for element graphics), and optional Status (e.g., N- for new work) fields within the layer name.  These examples highlight the system's flexibility for different disciplines (architect, second architect, civil engineer), element types, data types (graphics, tabulated information), and project phases (new work).

This image and text excerpt explain the layer naming convention defined in CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015), a code likely related to CAD layering for building information modeling (BIM) in architectural, engineering, and construction (AEC) projects.  The image, Figure 2, visually breaks down a sample layer name: `A-_WALLPARP_E-N`.

The image and accompanying text detail the five fields of the layer name:

1. **Originator:**  Identifies the discipline creating the layer (e.g., `A-` for Architect).  The text provides further examples like `A2` for a second architect and `C-` for Civil Engineer.

2. **Element:** Describes the building element the layer represents.  The example uses `WALLPARP`, with `WALL` being the main element and `PARP` (parapet) the sub-element.  Other examples include `AREACALC` (area calculation) and `ANOT` (annotation).

3. **Presentation:**  Indicates the type of information on the layer.  `E-` signifies "element graphics." Table 5, referenced but not shown, lists other codes. The text mentions "I-" for tabulated information and "D-" for dimensions.

4. **Status (Optional):**  Specifies the status of the element, particularly for additions and alterations.  `N` represents "new work." Table 6, also referenced but not shown, defines other status codes.

5. **User-Defined (Optional):** Allows for project-specific categorization.  The standard emphasizes the need for clear documentation of any user-defined fields.

The provided examples illustrate how these fields combine to create meaningful layer names:

* `A-_WALL----_E-`: Architect's layer with element graphics of walls.
* `A2_AREACALC_I-`: Second architect's layer with tabulated information on area calculation.
* `C-_ANOT----_D-`: Civil engineer's layer with dimensions.

The key concept is a structured, standardized approach to CAD layer naming, facilitating clear communication and data exchange between different project stakeholders.  This system allows for easy identification of the layer's creator, content, and purpose within the overall BIM model.

pages.summary: This excerpt from the Singapore Standard CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) details a standardized CAD layer naming convention for AEC projects, particularly for addition and alteration (A&A) works.  The convention uses a structured format: `Originator-Element-Presentation-Status-User-defined`.  Figure 2 illustrates this with the example `A-WALLPARP-E-N`, representing a new parapet wall (WALLPARP) graphic (E) created by the architect (A).  The standard defines codes for Originator (e.g., A-, A2, C-), Presentation (e.g., E- for element graphics, I- for tabulated information, D- for dimensions, referencing Table 5), and the optional Status field (e.g., N for new work, referencing Table 6).  The User-defined field offers further flexibility but requires clear documentation.  This standardized approach promotes clear communication and efficient data exchange among project stakeholders.  The document also includes licensing information indicating it was accessed by a user at CH2M HILL SINGAPORE PTE LTD under a single-user license from Enterprise Singapore.

elements.summary: CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines a structured CAD layer naming convention for AEC projects.  The layer name includes fields for Originator (e.g., A- for Architect), Element (main and sub-element), Presentation (e.g., E- for element graphics), and an optional Status (e.g., N- for new work).  A user-defined field allows for additional information.  The document provides examples demonstrating the application of this naming convention across different disciplines and use cases, including architectural walls, area calculations, civil annotations, drainage pipes, and structural slabs.  This standardized approach facilitates interoperability and clear communication between project stakeholders.

pages.summary: CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines a standardized CAD layer naming convention for AEC projects to improve interoperability and communication.  The convention uses a structured format: Originator_Element_Presentation_Status_User-Defined.  Originator identifies the discipline (e.g., A- for Architect, C- for Civil Engineer), Element defines the object type (e.g., WALL, AREACALC, SDRNPIPE), and Presentation specifies the display type (e.g., E- for element graphics, I- for tabular information, D- for dimensions).  An optional Status field (e.g., N- for new, R- for removal) and a User-Defined field provide further detail.  Numerous examples illustrate the convention's application across disciplines and use cases, including architectural walls and door schedules, civil annotations and drainage pipes, structural slabs, and mechanical and electrical systems.  The convention emphasizes clear documentation and communication regarding the use of the User-Defined field.

elements.summary:
The image is a scanned excerpt from Singapore Standard CP 83 : Part 1 : 2004 (2015), pertaining to the design and construction of sewers. The visible portion of the document focuses on sewer pipe bedding and surrounds. The image shows a cross-sectional drawing of a sewer pipe installed in a trench.  The key visual elements include:

* **Sewer Pipe:**  The central feature is a circular sewer pipe.
* **Bedding:** The pipe rests on a shaped bedding of granular material, specifically labeled as "Granular Bedding, Class B." The shape of the bedding conforms to the lower half of the pipe, providing support.
* **Surrounds/Backfill:** The material surrounding the pipe and filling the trench is labeled "Selected Backfill," indicating specific material requirements for this zone.
* **Side Support:**  While not explicitly labeled in this excerpt, the drawing implies compacted side support against the bedding material.

The image does not contain explicit numerical values for bedding thickness, pipe diameter, or trench dimensions.  It primarily illustrates the *qualitative* arrangement and layering of materials for proper pipe bedding and backfill.

The document is clearly identified as "CP 83 : Part 1 : 2004 (2015)."  The repeated licensing information indicates it was downloaded from the Singapore Standards eShop by Chang Kuo Wei of CH2M HILL SINGAPORE PTE LTD on 2019-08-29.  This contextual information confirms the image's source and intended use within an engineering project in Singapore.

The key concept illustrated is the importance of proper bedding and backfill for sewer pipes.  The granular bedding provides a uniform bearing surface for the pipe, preventing point loading and potential cracking. The selected backfill ensures proper drainage and minimizes differential settlement around the pipe, protecting it from damage due to soil movement.  The drawing emphasizes the structured nature of the bedding and surround, highlighting the engineering considerations necessary for long-term sewer integrity.

pages.summary: This document excerpt from Singapore Standard CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015) illustrates the proper bedding and backfill procedures for sewer pipes.  A cross-sectional drawing depicts a sewer pipe resting on Class B granular bedding, shaped to conform to the pipe's lower half, and surrounded by selected backfill.  This arrangement ensures uniform load distribution, prevents cracking, and minimizes differential settlement.  The image, obtained legally by Chang Kuo Wei of CH2M HILL SINGAPORE PTE LTD on August 29, 2019 (Order No: 6800055693), emphasizes the engineering principles behind achieving long-term sewer integrity through proper material selection and placement.
